body: This is a strong argument for splitting the server side stats from the normal stats.

Given various people' requirements I would suggest two new flags:

```
--stats-ignore-server-side-move
--stats-ignore-server-side-copy
```

This would give users flexibility what to include or not.
I was thinking of adding a new server side moves &or copies lines in the stats block. This wouldn't appear unless you did server side moves or copies.

I had a go with this - please give it a test!

[v1.64.0-beta.7191.b3c480be2.fix-7183-server-side-accounting](https://beta.rclone.org/branch/fix-7183-server-side-accounting/v1.64.0-beta.7191.b3c480be2.fix-7183-server-side-accounting/) on branch [fix-7183-server-side-accounting](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/tree/fix-7183-server-side-accounting) (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

It should show an extra line in the stats like this

```
Transferred:              0 B / 20.001 MiB, 0%, 0 B/s, ETA -
Checks:                22 / 37, 59%
Transferred:           10 / 69, 14%
Server Side:           10, 46.003 MiB (copies), 0, 0 B (moves)      <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
Elapsed time:        10.0s
```

Not sure I like the `,` separator between the number `10` and the bytes `64.003 MiB` above. Maybe an `@` sign? Or something else?

Have tried on my union/crypt/chunker remotes' chain:

```
2023/07/30 19:23:46 ERROR : Attempt 2/3 succeeded
2023/07/30 19:23:46 INFO  :
Transferred:   	  532.320 MiB / 532.320 MiB, 100%, 429.098 KiB/s, ETA 0s
Checks:               412 / 412, 100%
Renamed:              204
Transferred:          204 / 204, 100%
Server Side:            0, 0 B (copies), 204, 532.182 MiB (moves)
Elapsed time:     13m30.5s
```
Looks good. I will keep using it from now on to validate in real life:)

> Server Side:            0, 0 B (copies), 204, 532.182 MiB (moves)
> Not sure I like the `,` separator between the number `10` and the bytes `64.003 MiB` above. Maybe an `@` sign? Or something else?

I see what you mean...

what about:

`Server Side:            0 copies: 0 B, 204 moves: 532.182 MiB`

hopefully more people on the forum will test and provide some feedback.
Added to the 1.64 milestone since we already have a tentative build.

issue.title: chunker overlay's reporting of transfer information is not super useful always, and chunker interaction with --transfers in a funky way

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
![chunkercouldbemorreliable](https://github.com/mikf/gallery-dl/assets/16432525/e074e86c-ffc6-40af-9728-5e7bddf006c1)


As you can see here the chunker overlay uploads chunkers then renames them via a server-side move which doubles the reported bandwidth and or filesize transferred and makes bandwidth reporting inaccurate. Now I could do some math to determine the bandwidth usage myself, BUT, if the filesize transfered data measurement is wrong, my math will result in a wrong average bandwidth used result also.

Also maybe even more critically... I find that the chunker overlay almost randomly multiplies the --transfers flag.

I think the correct function would be for a manually entered --transfers flag to overwrite some of chunker's choices.
 
If I set --transfers 8 and then upload 8 files that are broken into 16 total ChunkerOverlayFileChunks; it will make rclone function as if I had set -transfers 16... And if I'm trying to carefully calibrate my rclone copy/sync command in order to properly fit inside some draconian api call restriction throttling.. I'd rather in the above example for rclone to treat --transfers 8 like --transfers 4. But I can't just type --transfers 4 because if I'm uploading even larger files maybe the 8 files are broken into 80 ChunkerOverlayFileChunks and even if I entered --transfers 4 it would behave as if I'd entered --transfers 40

So ideally when a chunker overlay is told to upload 8 files at once, that should be 8 ChunkerOverlayFileChunks. AKA, --transfers 8 always means to transfer 8 source files at once. It also usually means to transfers 8 destination files at once. But in a chunker overlay those two 8's are not equal. --transfers 8 in rclone needs to always transfer 8 destination files. Which is almost always 8 source files. But inside a chunkeroverlay, 8 destination files could be anywhere from 1-8 source files. Does that make any sense to anyone but me?

TLDR: the chunker overlay is harder to control, and harder to monitor than other overlays. I think if some genius reads this message, they could think of a way to improve it :)

body:
After fiddling around with various formats

```
Server Side:            0, 0 B (copies), 204, 532.182 MiB (moves)
Server Side:            0 copies: 0 B, 204 moves: 532.182 MiB
Server Side:            0 (copies 0 B), 204 (moves 532.182 MiB)
Server Side:            0 copies 0 B, 204 moves 532.182 MiB
```

I decided to go for two lines. The Moves/Copies lines will only appear if non zero which I think will make things easier to understand. The `@` sign giving a definite visual delimiter with approximately the correct semantics!

```
Server Side Copies:     17 @ 532.120 MiB
Server Side Moves:       9 @ 32.320 MiB
```

I've merged this to master now which means it will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org/) in 15-30 minutes and released in v1.64
